Handling Model Entities

Jonas Förster & Jürgen Pahle

2017-07-31

Initial Setup

library(tidyverse)
library(CoRC)
loadExamples(2)
#> [[1]]
#> # A copasi model reference:
#> Model name: "Bacterial chemotaxis model"
#> @ref is set to: <pointer: 0x7fd33bff64f0>
#> Number of compartments: 1
#> Number of species: 21
#> Number of reactions: 14
getSpecies()
#> # A tibble: 21 x 8
#>       name compartment       type initial.concentration initial.number
#>      <chr>       <chr>      <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>
#>  1    CheA compartment  reactions                  5.30       4468.429
#>  2   CheAp compartment  reactions                  0.00          0.000
#>  3    CheB compartment  reactions                  0.28        236.068
#>  4   CheBp compartment  reactions                  0.00          0.000
#>  5    CheY compartment  reactions                  9.70       8178.069
#>  6   CheYp compartment  reactions                  0.00          0.000
#>  7    CheR compartment      fixed                  0.16        134.896
#>  8 Tactive compartment assignment                  0.00          0.000
#>  9    CheZ compartment  reactions                  3.80       3203.779
#> 10      T0 compartment  reactions                  5.30       4468.429
#> # ... with 11 more rows, and 3 more variables: concentration <dbl>,
#> #   number <dbl>, key <chr>

Identifying entities

There are at the moment 5 different types of model entities supported.

species("CheA")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheA]"
compartment("comp")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment]"
quantity("a")
#> Error: Could not match global quantity(s) "a".
reaction("Che B phosph")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Reactions[Che B phosph]"
parameter("4).kR")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Reactions[Rm4],ParameterGroup=Parameters,Parameter=kR"

These functions return CommonNames when a species is identified. They are vectorized and will always return a vector of identified entities of the same length or throw an error. This mean behavior for NA or non-uniquely matching strings is throw an error. REGEX support could be implemented but under these limitations, regex strings would also have to yield unique matches.

species("CheY")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY]"
species("CheYp")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheYp]"
species(c("CheY", "CheYp"))
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY]" 
#> [2] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheYp]"
species("Che")
#> Error: Could not correctly identify some species:
#> "Che" matches species "CheA", "CheAp", "CheB", "CheBp", "CheY", "CheYp", "CheR", "CheZ".
species(c(NA, "CheY"))
#> Error: !anyNA(key) is not TRUE
species("failure")
#> Error: Could not match species "failure".

CommonNames are generally what is used by CoRC to identify entities. In cases, where a key is clear to always expect the same kind of entity, identification can also be handled by the function itself.

getSpecies(key = "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY]")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 8
#>    name compartment      type initial.concentration initial.number
#>   <chr>       <chr>     <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1  CheY compartment reactions                   9.7       8178.069
#> # ... with 3 more variables: concentration <dbl>, number <dbl>, key <chr>
getSpecies(key = species("CheY"))
#> # A tibble: 1 x 8
#>    name compartment      type initial.concentration initial.number
#>   <chr>       <chr>     <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1  CheY compartment reactions                   9.7       8178.069
#> # ... with 3 more variables: concentration <dbl>, number <dbl>, key <chr>
getSpecies(key = "CheY")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 8
#>    name compartment      type initial.concentration initial.number
#>   <chr>       <chr>     <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1  CheY compartment reactions                   9.7       8178.069
#> # ... with 3 more variables: concentration <dbl>, number <dbl>, key <chr>
getSpecies("CheY")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 8
#>    name compartment      type initial.concentration initial.number
#>   <chr>       <chr>     <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1  CheY compartment reactions                   9.7       8178.069
#> # ... with 3 more variables: concentration <dbl>, number <dbl>, key <chr>
getSpecies("Che")
#> Error: Could not correctly identify some species:
#> "Che" matches species "CheA", "CheAp", "CheB", "CheBp", "CheY", "CheYp", "CheR", "CheZ".

Using References

The identifying functions can also return value references if specified. Such references are needed as input for example to define Parameter Estimations.

species("CheY", reference = "InitialConcentration")
#> [1] "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY],Reference=InitialConcentration"

These function however can not give any clues about what references are available.

species("CheY", reference = "failure")
#> Error: Failed to gather some references.

To help with this, functions implemented to get model values have similar functions that return references instead of values.

str(getSpecies("CheY"))
#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    1 obs. of  8 variables:
#>  $ name                 : chr "CheY"
#>  $ compartment          : chr "compartment"
#>  $ type                 : chr "reactions"
#>  $ initial.concentration: num 9.7
#>  $ initial.number       : num 8178
#>  $ concentration        : num 9.7
#>  $ number               : num 8178
#>  $ key                  : chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY]"
str(getSpeciesReferences("CheY"))
#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    1 obs. of  8 variables:
#>  $ name                 : chr "CheY"
#>  $ compartment          : chr "compartment"
#>  $ type                 : chr "reactions"
#>  $ initial.concentration: chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY],Reference=In"| __truncated__
#>  $ initial.number       : chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY],Reference=In"| __truncated__
#>  $ concentration        : chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY],Reference=Concentration"
#>  $ number               : chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY],Reference=ParticleNumber"
#>  $ key                  : chr "CN=Root,Model=Bacterial chemotaxis model,Vector=Compartments[compartment],Vector=Metabolites[CheY]"

Being able to use [CheYp]_0 instead of a full CN would probably lead to more intuitive results (see Article: Issues).
